I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The 11th Five-Year Plan (11FYP) of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) will be 
prepared in 2005 and early 2006.1 The 11FYP will  be crucial  for designing strategies and 
programs for socioeconomic development in 2006–2010. As stated in the Country Strategy and 
Program Update (CSPU) 2005–2007 for the PRC, supporting the preparation of 11FYP is one 
of the priorities of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) operation in the PRC. During the 2005 
Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  requested  that  ADB  provide  technical 
assistance (TA) to support the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) to study 
strategies for foreign loans utilization and regional cooperation in the Asia and Pacific region, 
including subregional cooperation in Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) 2 and  Central  Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC), 3 areas for the 11FYP.  The fact-finding meetings 
were  conducted  with  NDRC  in  March–May 2005 to  determine  NDRC’s actual needs and 
reached  understanding  on  the  TA’s  impact,  outputs,  implementation  arrangements,  cost, 
financing arrangements, and terms of reference.4 The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.   
 
II.   ISSUES 
 
2.  In the past 25 years, using foreign loans has helped PRC’s economic developmentb y 
filling  fiscal  and  foreign  reserve  gaps  and  improving  the  country’s  infrastructure  for 
transportation, energy, and environmental protection.  It has also helped social development 
including education and health, poverty reduction, and rural development.  Foreign loans have 
become an important channel  for introducing advanced technologies and management skills 
from abroad.  
 
3.  However, some fundamental changes have taken place since the late 1990s. Due to the 
rapid increase in foreign direct investment and  improvement of  fiscal management, foreign 
exchange reserves surged and fiscal revenue increased more than 18% annually on average in 
the past  10 years. Infrastructure bottlenecks have also been reduced as the Government 
invested heavily in infrastructure in the past 10 years or more.  
 
4.  PRC’s long-term development goal is to quadruple the 2000 gross domestic product and 
achieve a xiaokang (all-around prosperous) society by 2020. To achieve this overall goal, the 
Government adopted new development strategies that emphasize balanced development and a 
harmonized society. Accordingly, priorities for using foreign loans, particularly those mobilized 
through sovereign borrowing, should be adjusted. During the meeting between PRC President 
Hu Jingtao and ADB President Kuroda in April 2005, President Hu emphasized that ADB should 
expand the scope of its lending assistance from infrastructure construction to agriculture, public 
health, education, and environmental protection. He also suggested that ADB enhance its role 
in regional and subregional cooperation.  
 
                                                 
1  Starting from 1953, the Government of the People’s Republic of China developed 5-year plans (FYPs) for 
socioeconomic development every 5 years. Except for 1963–1965, the Government had formulated 10 FYPs by 
2004.  
2  Greater Mekong Subregion member countries include Cambodia, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Myanmar, 
Thailand, Viet Nam, and PRC (Yunnan province and newly joined Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region). 
3  Central Asian Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) member countries include Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, 
Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and PRC (Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region). 
4  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 5 February 2005.

2   
5.  Under such changes of environment, some new issues on foreign loans utilization have 
emerged.  For  example,  (i)  what  would  be  the  appropriate  volume  of  continued  external 
borrowing in view of the huge foreign exchange reserves, (ii) what would be the role of 
sovereign borrowing in the thrust to realize more balanced economic growth and a harmonized 
society, (iii) what would be the potential for subsovereign and nonsovereign borrowing, (iv) what 
would be the optimal mixture of sovereign and subsovereign/nonsovereign borrowings, and (v) 
what would be the most appropriate management tools for external debt management that can 
guide the sectoral/geographic allocation of borrowed resources. This TA will investigate those 
issues and formulate strategies, policies, and measures on utilization of foreign loans in the 
coming 11FYP period.  
 
6.  With  PRC’s  incraesing  integration  into  the  world  and  Asian  economies,  regional 
cooperation has become more and more important for the country. The Asian financial crisis 
and the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) underscore the importance of 
regional  cooperation  so  that  countries  can  jointly  meet  common  challenges  and  prosper 
together.  The PRC is actively participating in many regional cooperation arrangements in the 
Asia  and  Pacific  region  including  the  Asia-Pacific  Economic  Cooperation  (APEC)  Forum, 
ASEAN+3 (PRC, Japan, and Republic of Korea), and Boao Forum. As the most populous 
country in the world, the PRC should play a more proactive role in regional cooperation in the 
next 5-10 years.  
 
7.  At the subregional level, the PRC is actively participating in ADB’s initiativesi ncluding 
GMS, CAREC, and the PRC-Mongolia Subregion (Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region). The 
Government is striving to improve cross-border trade, transport, and resources protection to 
reduce poverty in those areas where many of the poor live. Although substantial progress has 
been made, subregional cooperation faces new challenges in the coming 5-10 years.  For 
instance,  PRC’s  participation  in  subregional  cooperation  has  focused  on  the  piecemeal 
expansions of local economies promoted by bordering provinces. It is necessary to strengthen 
coordination at the central level and integration with the national development program. 
 
8.  To identify difficulties and promote regional/subregional cooperation, the TA will review 
experiences, identify major issues, and formulate guidelines, main goals, and PRC’s strategies 
in regional/subregional cooperation during the 11FYP period.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is to develop strategies and plans on foreign loans utilization and  regional 
cooperation in the Asia and Pacific region, including subregional cooperation in GMS and 
CAREC areas during the 11FYP period. Well-designed strategies and plans for efficient use of 
foreign loans and wider involvement in regional and subregional cooperation will contribute to 
maintain more sustainable growth and build a more harmonized society in the long term.  
 
10.  Key  findings  and  recommendations  will  be  provided  to  relevant  ministries  for 
consideration during the annual National People’s Congress N(PC) meeting in March 2006 
when  the  11FYP  will  be  deliberated.  In  addition,  the  TA  study  reports  will  be  further 
disseminated through policy workshops, seminars, and publications.

3 
 
B.    Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will be carried out in three parts that correspond to three strategic topics. They 
are (i) past performance and future strategies for foreign loan utilization; (ii) overall scope and 
strategic  approaches  for  more  proactive  engagement  in  regional  cooperation;  and  (iii) 
opportunities  and  further  measures  for  more  active  participation  in  GMS  and  CAREC 
subregional  programs.  In  carrying  out  the  three  studies,  the  TA  will  follow  a  general 
methodology, that first critically reviews past experience, assess impacts and ascertain lessons; 
then identify future strategic options and policy choices; and finally, develop actionable plans for 
implementation during the 11FYP period.  
 
12.  The  TA  will  combine  international  experiences  with  domestic  practice  in  all  three 
components by presenting strategies applied and policies and successful experiences in other 
countries, especially similar developing countries. ADB will work with the executing agency to 
identify international experts and top domestic experts who are working or researching in 
relevant areas.  As distinguished resource persons for international workshops, international 
experts will focus on presenting experience and practices in their countries or organizations. As 
well-selected individual consultants, domestic experts will undertake in-depth studies to develop 
the three strategies by integrating international experiences and local practices.  
 
13.  Key  activities  for  the  three  strategic  studies  will  have  four  logical  components:  (i) 
presentation  of  international  experience  and  consultation;  (ii)  assessment,  analysis,  and 
forecast; (iii) consultation with policy makers, think tanks, academia, private sector, and civil 
society; and (iv) dissemination of findings. In component (i), three international workshops will 
be  held  to  present  the  international  experts’  findings  on  foreign  loans  utilization,  regional 
cooperation, and subregional cooperation. Several face-to-face consulting meetings between 
international experts, domestic experts, and NDRC staff will follow. In component (ii), domestic 
experts will undertake detailed studies by collecting data, incorporating international experts’ 
findings, and conducting econometric analysis and case studies to complete the first draft 
reports. In component (iii), several consulting meetings/seminars will be held to discuss the 
preliminary findings and to get feedback from  policy makers, think tanks, academia, private 
sector, and civil society. On the basis of  these discussions and consultation, the domestic 
experts  will  revise  their  reports.  The  final  reports  will  be  provided  to  policy  makers  for 
incorporation in the 11FYP and dissemination through conferences, publications, and media.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The  TA  cost  is  estimated  at  $630,000  equivalent,  comprising  $150,000  in  foreign 
exchange and $480,000 equivalent in local currency. ADB will provide $500,000 equivalent on a 
grant basis from the ADB-funded TA program to cover the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$350,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The Government will finance the balance of the 
local currency cost, equivalent to $130,000, by providing counterpart staff, workshop facilities, 
and logistical support. Appendix 2 gives the cost estimates and the financing plan.  
 
D.   Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  NDRC’s Foreign Capital Utilization Departmnet (FCUD), with the broad mandate for 
planning in foreign capital utilization and regional/subregional cooperation, will be the Executing 
Agency for the TA. FCUD will ensure close coordination with central Government ministries, 
local government agencies,  and research institutions. It will monitor TA implementation and 
review  study  findings.  A  project  implementation  team  comprising  FCUD’s  deputy  director

4   
general, division chiefs, and project officers will be responsible for the TA’s daily operations. 
FCUD will provide office facilities and access to all relevant information and data.   
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months, beginning in  August 2005 and ending in 
August  2006.    ADB  will  engage  international  experts  as  resource  persons  and  domestic 
consultants as individual consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. 
The  international  experts,  with  expertise  in  practices  in  foreign  capital  utilization  and 
regional/subregional cooperation, will prepare papers, present them in international workshops, 
and provide  consultation. The domestic experts (40 person-months) will have expertise in 
institutional lending, commercial lending, foreign capital utilization strategy, regional cooperation 
in the Asia and Pacific region, and subregional cooperation in GMS and CAREC areas.  
 
17.  The consultants will work in three subgroups, each led by a team leader. Considering 
the large group of consultants and the lack of familiarity of most domestic consultants with ADB 
procedures, two administrative assistants will be recruited to deal with administrative issues, 
including  coordinating  with  international  and  domestic  consultants,  organizing  workshops, 
preparing documents for disbursement, and interpreting and translating. NDRC will provide 
office accommodation for them. Appendix 3 gives the terms of reference for consultants. 
 
18.  Three international workshops will be organized to introduce international experience 2 
months after inception meetings. Related consulting meetings will follow. Each international 
consultant will submit a paper  before the workshops. Domestic consultants will submit  their 
interim reports by the end of the 4 months. The interim reports will analyze all components of 
the TA and give recommendations. The consultants will submit their draft final reports within 8 
months. The team leaders will submit their final reports, incorporating comments from the 
Government, ADB, and other stakeholders, within 1 month  after receiving such comments. 
FCUD will publish the final report. 
 
19.  Equipment  for  consultants  in  carrying  out  the  TA  will  be  procured  under  ADB’s 
Guidelines  for  Procurement.  The  TA  funds  will  be  disbursed  to  and  liquidated  by  FCUD 
according to procedures and requirements of ADB’s advance payment facility .
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Support for the Preparation of the 11th 
Five-Year Plan, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The consultants—9 international and 12 domestic—will be engaged individually. They 
will be divided into three groups that will be tasked to provide advisory services for the following 
objectives and activities. 
 
A.  Strategic Study on Foreign Loans Utilization in the Medium- and Long-Term 
  (Group A) 
 
2.  Each of 4 international experts will be invited to draft and present a paper and conduct 
consultations with officials of National Development  and Reform Commission (NDRC) and 
domestic experts. The experts will be from countries whose experiences are of interest to the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC). The experts will describe the history of and practices in 
foreign  loans  utilization,  and  make  policy  and  implementation  suggestions  to  formulate  a 
strategy for foreign loans utilization in the 11th Five-Year Plan (11FYP).  
 
3.  Four domestic experts will be employed for a total of 13 person-months. One of them will 
be nominated as subgroup leader and will coordinate the work of the three other experts. 
 
1.  Foreign Loans Utilization Expert (4 person-months)  
 
4.  As subgroup leader,  the expert should be familiar with the history of foreign capital 
utilization in the PRC, have expertise in macroeconomic planning and policy formulation, and 
have experience in formulating national development strategies. The expert’s activities include 
the following: 
 
(i)  Analyze and summarize the achievements and  primary experiences in PRC's 
utilization of foreign loans in the past 25 years. The analysis will be focused on the 
utilized amount, the source and investment orientation as well as the role (in the 
national economy) of foreign loans. 
 
(ii)  Forecast  the  external  and  domestic  environment  facing  PRC’s  foreign  capital 
utilization in the next 5–10 years. 
 
(iii)  Formulate the medium- to long-term strategy on PRC’s foreign capital utilization . 
 
(iv)  Provide policy suggestions and recommendations. 
 
(v)  Consolidate  the  final  report,  incorporating  domestic  consultants’  inputs  and 
international experiences. 
 
2.  International Institutions’  Lending Expert(3   person-months) 
 
5.  The expert’s work will include the following :
 
(i)  Incorporate international consultants’  findings onin ternational institutions’  lendin.g  
 
(ii)  Analyze  the  industrial  distribution  of  international  ending  that  flowed  in  and 
estimate the scale and scope of using these loans in 5–10 years.

Appendix 3    9              
(iii)  Analyze different regions’  demand for loans, their repayment capabilities, and 
different ways of using the loans.   
 
(iv)  Formulate  policies  by  incorporating  development  plans  and  policies  for  the 
borrowing sectors and regions. 
 
3.  Bilateral Lending Expert (3 person-months) 
 
6.  The expert’sta sks include the following: 
 
(i)  Incorporate international experts’  findings on bilateral lending.   
 
(ii)  Analyze industrial distribution of bilateral lending and forecast the scale and scope 
of using these loans in the next 5–10 years.  
 
(iii)  Analyze different regions’  demand for loans, their repayment capabilities, and 
different ways of in using the loans.  
 
(iv)  Formulate more scientific and rational policies by incorporating development plans 
and policies for the borrowing sectors and regions. 
 
4.  Global Commercial Lending Expert (3 person-months) 
 
7.  The expert’s tasks include the following :
 
(i)  Study the international capital market and availability of financing by analyzing the 
changes and trends in that market. Estimate the reasonable amount of borrowing 
from international commercial banks and examine ways for utilization.  
 
(ii)  Update and revise laws and regulations regarding international commercial loans 
based on a review of existing policies. 
  
(iii)  Formulate financing policies and a management pattern that can promote fair 
competition between foreign and domestic enterprises. 
 
B.  Strategic Study on Regional Cooperation in the Asia and Pacific Region (Group B) 
 
8.  Each of 3 international experts will be invited to draft and present a paper and to conduct 
consultations with NDRC officials and domestic experts. The international experts will be from 
countries whose experiences are of interest to the PRC. The experts will introduce the history of 
and practices in regional cooperation in the Asia and Pacific region, and make policy and 
implementation suggestions to formulate a strategy for regional cooperation in the 11FYP.  
 
9.  Four domestic experts will be employed for a total of 13 person-months. One of them will 
be nominated as subgroup leader and will coordinate the work of the three other experts. 
 
1.  Regional Cooperation (4 person-months) 
 
10.  As subgroup leader, the expert should be familiar with the history of regional cooperation, 
have expertise  in macroeconomic planning and policy formulation, and have experience in 
formulating national development strategies. The expert will be responsible for these tasks:

(i)  Formulate  PRC’s  strategy,  define  areas  of  cooperation  and  implementation 
arrangements in regional cooperation with the Asia and Pacific region during the 
11FYP period. 
 
(ii)  Recommend  policies  for  further  improving  PRC’s  involvement  i nregional 
cooperation. 
 
(iii)  Consolidate  the  final  report,  incorporating  domestic  consultants’  ipnuts  and

2.  Intraregional Trade Expert (3 person-months) 
 
11.  The expert’s responsibilities include the following :
 
(i)  Review the experience in intraregional trade.  
 
(ii)  Identify problems in current regional trade cooperation.  
 
(iii)  Figure out risks and uncertainties in trade cooperation in the Asia and Pacific 
region for the next 5–10 years. 
 
3.  International Capital Flow Expert (3 person-months) 
 
12.  The expert’s responsibilities follow :
 
(i)  Review the experience in capital inflow and outflow in the Asia and Pacific region.  
 
(ii)  Identify problems in the past practice.  
 
(iii)  Figure out risks and uncertainties in capital flow in the Asia and Pacific region for 
the next 5–10 years. 
 
4.  Regional Conferences and Forums Expert (3 person-months) 
 
13.  The expert’s repsonsibilities are the following: 
 
(i)  Review  the  role  the  PRC  plays  in  regional  conferences  (e.g.,  Asia-Pacific 
Economic Cooperation,  Shanghai Cooperation Organization)  and forums (e.g., 
Boao Forum).  
 
(ii)  Identify problems in the past practice.  
 
(iii)  Suggest how to strengthen the impact of regional conferences and forums on 
support for PRC’s socioeconomic development in the next –510 years.

C.  Strategic Study on Subregional Cooperation in CAREC and GMS Areas (Group C) 
 
14.  Two international experts will be invited to draft and present a paper and to conduct 
consultations with NDRC officials and other domestic experts. The experts will be from countries 
whose experiences are of interest to the PRC. These experts will introduce the history of and 
practices  in  subregional  cooperation  in  CAREC  and  GMS  areas,  and  make  policy  and 
implementation suggestions to formulate a strategy for subregional cooperation in the 11FYP.  
 
15.  Four domestic experts will be employed for a total of 14 person-months. Two of them will 
be nominated as subgroup leader and deputy subgroup leader, respectively, and will coordinate 
the work of the two other experts.  
 
1.  Subregional Cooperation Expert (CAREC) (4 person-months) 
 
16.  As  the  subgroup  leader,  the  expert  should  be  familiar  with  historical  changes in 
subregional cooperation, have expertise in macroeconomic planning and policy formulation, and 
have experience in formulating national development strategies. The expert will have these 
tasks:  
 
(i)  Formulate  strategy  and  define  areas  of  cooperation  and  implementation 
arrangements for regional cooperation with CAREC countries during the 11FYP 
period. 
 
(ii)  Recommend policies for further improvement of PRC’s involvement in CAREC . 
 
(iii)  Consolidate  the  final  report  and  incorporate  domestic  consultants’  inputs  and 
international experiences. 
 
2.  Subregional Cooperation Expert (GMS) (4 person-months) 
 
17.  As the deputy subgroup leader, the expert will be responsible for these tasks: 
 
(i)  Formulate strategy, define areas of cooperation and implementation arrangements 
for regional cooperation with GMS countries during the 11FYP period. 
 
(ii)  Recommend policies for further improvement of PRC’s involvement in GMS .
 
(iii)  Consolidate  the  final  report,  incorporating  domestic  consultants’  inputs  and 
international experiences. 
 
3.  CAREC and PRC Expert (3 person-months) 
 
18.  The expert’s responsibilities are as follows :
 
(i)  Review PRC’s experience in subregional cooperation in CAREC areas . 
 
(ii)  Identify problems that existed in the past practice.  
 
(iii)  Figure out risks and uncertainties in subregional cooperation in CAREC areas for 
the next 5–10 years.
